name: Albert Park
history: The Albert Park Circuit, a semi-street track in Melbourne's parkland, hosted its first F1 Grand Prix in 1996 after renovations amid COVID delays, featuring a mix of fast corners and unforgiving walls that create a challenging and party-like season opener.

name: Shanghai International Circuit
history: Opened in 2004 as China's first purpose-built F1 circuit, Shanghai International features long straights and tight hairpins designed by Hermann Tilke, hosting dramatic races like Lewis Hamilton's multiple wins and returning in 2025 after a five-year absence.

name: Suzuka International Racing Course
history: Built in 1962 and joining the F1 calendar in 1987, Suzuka's figure-eight layout with high-speed corners like 130R has hosted iconic races, including multiple championships decided there for drivers like Michael Schumacher.

name: Bahrain International Circuit
history: The Bahrain International Circuit debuted in 2004 as the Middle East's first F1 venue, featuring four layouts including the endurance Outer Circuit, and has been a night race since 2014, known for its abrasive surface and strategic overtaking zones.

name: Jeddah Street Circuit
history: Jeddah's Corniche Circuit, the world's fastest street track, joined F1 in 2021 on the Red Sea waterfront with 27 corners at speeds over 300km/h, designed by Tilke for high-speed action and hosting Max Verstappen's title-clinching win.

name: Miami International Autodrome
history: Miami's Hard Rock Stadium circuit debuted in 2022 around the venue, blending street and permanent sections with a long straight for DRS overtakes, attracting celebrities and marking F1's expansion in the US market.

name: Autodromo Enzo e Dino Ferrari (Imola)
history: Imola's Autodromo Enzo e Dino Ferrari, opened in 1953, hosted F1 from 1981 and the tragic 1994 San Marino GP, leading to safety reforms; recent resurfacing has restored its challenging flow with elevation changes.

name: Circuit de Monaco
history: The Monaco Grand Prix dates to 1929 on public roads around Monte Carlo, becoming a F1 staple in 1950 with its narrow, twisty layout demanding precision; it's famed as the 'billionaire's playground' with zero overtakes in some races.

name: Circuit de Barcelona-Catalunya
history: Opened in 1991, Barcelona-Catalunya has been a pre-season testing hub and F1 race venue, featuring a mix of high-speed corners for car development and recent upgrades to the final sector for better overtaking.

name: Circuit Gilles-Villeneuve
history: Named after Quebec racer Gilles Villeneuve, the Ile Notre-Dame circuit debuted in 1978 with fast straights and the 'Wall of Champions' in the final chicane, hosting thrilling races like the 2011 Safety Car controversy.

name: Red Bull Ring
history: Originally the Osterreichring since 1969, the shortened Red Bull Ring (post-1997 rebuild) features dramatic elevation and short lap times, often double-header venue and home to Red Bull's dominance.

name: Silverstone Circuit
history: Britain's Silverstone, built on a WWII airfield in 1948, hosted the first F1 race in 1950 with high-speed corners like Copse and Maggotts, remaining a fan favorite for its heritage and British GP atmosphere.

name: Circuit de Spa-Francorchamps
history: Spa's Ardennes forest layout, opened in 1921 and F1 since 1950, is legendary for Eau Rouge and unpredictable weather, undergoing safety updates while preserving its 7km challenge.

name: Hungaroring
history: The Hungaroring, built in 1986 behind the Iron Curtain, features 14 turns in a go-kart-like layout around Budapest, often called 'Monaco without walls' for its overtaking difficulties.

name: Circuit Zandvoort
history: Zandvoort's dunes circuit raced F1 from 1952-1985 before returning in 2021 with banking and modifications for Max Verstappen's home fans, blending nostalgia with modern safety.

name: Autodromo Nazionale Monza
history: Monza's 'Temple of Speed', opened in 1922 in Royal Villa park, has hosted every F1 season since 1950 with its high-speed oval and chicanes, site of many Ferrari triumphs.

name: Baku City Circuit
history: Baku's hybrid street-permanent track debuted in 2016 on the Caspian Sea, combining castle walls and a 2.2km straight for chaotic races like the 2017 Virtual Safety Car win.

name: Marina Bay Street Circuit
history: Singapore's night race since 2008, the first in F1 history, winds through Marina Bay's landmarks with 23 corners, known for its physical demands and humid conditions.

name: Circuit of the Americas
history: COTA in Austin opened in 2012 with Hermann Tilke's design inspired by classics, featuring the 133m elevation 'Drs Test' hill and massive American fan events.

name: Autodromo Hermanos Rodriguez
history: Mexico City's high-altitude track, first F1 in 1963, was revamped in 2015 around the iconic stadium, challenging engines with thin air and passionate crowds.

name: Autodromo Jose Carlos Pace (Interlagos)
history: Interlagos, built in 1936 and F1 since 1973, features undulating layout in Sao Paulo's suburbs, site of dramatic titles like Senna's 1991 win amid rain.

name: Las Vegas Street Circuit
history: Las Vegas debuted in 2023 on the Strip with a 6.2km layout past casinos, starting at midnight for global appeal and high speeds on its long straight.

name: Losail International Circuit
history: Losail, built in 1998 for MotoGP, hosted F1 sprint weekends from 2021 with smooth surface and floodlit night racing, closing the season finale in 2024.

name: Yas Marina Circuit
history: Yas Marina on Yas Island debuted in 2009 as a twilight race, redesigned in 2022 for more overtaking, and has ended seasons with controversies like the 2021 title decider.
